Award.AbstractNarration:
A request is made to fund Oceanographic Instrumentation on R/V Atlantis, a 274? general purpose research vessel, and R/V Armstrong, a new 238? multidisciplinary vessel. Both are operated by WHOI as part of the U.S. Academic Fleet which is scheduled by the University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS). Both are owned by the U.S. Navy, have state-of-the-art instrumentation and support all disciplines of oceanographic research. The vessels work in all the world?s oceans supporting science funded primarily by U.S government agencies. R/V Atlantis is specifically outfitted for launching and servicing Alvin, the human occupied submersible as well as other vehicles of the National Deep Submergence Facility (NDSF).

In 2017, R/V Atlantis completed 297 days at sea. NSF funded projects accounted for 69% of the total sailing schedule (205 days). In 2018, Atlantis is scheduled for 303 days with NSF accounting for 236 of those or 78%. R/V Armstrong sailed 230 total days in 2017 and 71 of these, 31%, were for NSF. Additionally, 73 days (32%) were for NSF-OOI. The vessel is scheduled for 251 days in 2018, 52% of which (129 days) are for NSF.

Oceanographic Instrumentation requested in this proposal includes:

1) Sonardyne USBL Tracking Beacons $29,750
2) Seabird CTD and Rosette Connector Upgrades $149,812
$179,562
Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 13-589). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2018 NSF funded the R/V Neil Armstrong a Sonardyne Ultra Short Baseline navigation (USBL) tracking system mounted on a permanently installed Kongsberg HiPap stem mounted in the hull. Demand for this system had increased considerably as the use of autonomous and tethered vehicles and instruments have become more important in underwater research. The ability of the ship to accurately track these vehicles is critical to the success of the science missions and safe recovery of the underwater vehicles. In many cases, knowledge of an accurate underwater location for an instrument is critical to fulfillment of that instruments mission.

Fundamental to the use of USBL was the installation of beacons mounted on the vehicle or instrument frame. These beacons provide both the return signal necessary for accurate navigation and telemetry indicating system status and other mission parameters. As the number of vehicles deployed on individual cruises increases the need for multiple beacons has also increased. In most cases it is not possible or desirable to continually remove a beacon from one vehicle or instrument and mount is on another between dives. Attempting to do this has led to both delays, and opportunities for inducing errors which cause mission failure.

In order to provide tracking capabilities to all users, both R/V Atlantis and R/V Neil Armstrong are required to carry additional beacons that cover all users. WHOI had only one single 3,000 meter beacon which was insufficient to meet the present and future needs of the science community. With permanent shipboard beacons, we are now able to provide the status of the system and are ready to for deployment and available to all users without prior notice.
